trial_identification.scientifictitle: An observational, cross-sectional study on the effect of maternal blood folic acid and total folate status on human milk folate-binding protein concentration and infant folate status at 8 weeks postpartum.

conditions.healthcondition: Other nutritional indices (vitamins B6 and B12, choline, betaine, dimethylglycine, methioinine, homocysteine, cysteine, cystathionine, iron, zinc, and selenium)

interventions.interventions: The primary exposure of interest is the blood folic acid concentration and blood folate status of the mother. The study aims to observe the effect of maternal blood folate status on milk folate-binding protein concentration and on infant blood folate status. Blood folic acid status and blood total folate status of the mother are assessed at 8 weeks postpartum (the folate status of the mother will be conditional on the previous folate and folic acid intake, most likely over the course of the pregnancy as steady state concentrations are only reached after 40 or more weeks). Folate-binding protein concentration and total folate in breast-milk at 8 weeks postpartum is also measured as an exposure variable in relation to infant folate status.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Human milk folate-binding protein concentration assessed by ELISA assay
Infant total serum folate status assessed by isotope dilution-liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry
Infant total whole-blood folate status assessed by isotope dilution-liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Blood one-carbon metabolites of the mother and infant assessed by isotope dilution-liquid chromatography-tandem mass spectrometry methods

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Maternal age 18 to 42 years Healthy singleton infant born between 37 to 42 weeks gestation inclusive Exclusive breastfeeding
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: High risk pregnancy (eclampsia or HELLP syndrome) Diabetes Cardiac disease Renal disease Inflammatory bowel syndrome Coeliac Disease Gastric bypass surgery Medications (valproic acid, carbamazepine, phenobarbital, primidone, methotrexate, fluorouracil, premetrexed, pyrimethamine, trimethoprim, thiazide diuretics, sulfasalazine, pancreatin, cholestryramine, colestipol, metformin)

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Department of Human Nutrition University of Otago PO Box 56 Dunedin 9054

fundingsource.fundingaddress: Research and Enterprise Office Centre for Innovation University of Otago PO Box 56 Dunedin 9054

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The aim of the study is to measure the amount of folate-binding protein in human milk and to determine if it is down-regulated by high folic acid consumption using maternal blood folic acid and total folate status as biomarkers.

ethicscommitee.ethicname: University of Otago Human Ethics Committee
